verses.text: God of my ancestors, Lord of mercy, you who made all things by your word,
verses.comment: The reference to God creating by His word connects to the Logos in John 1, highlighting the role of divine wisdom in creation.

verses.text: and by your wisdom have formed humankind to rule over the creatures you have made,
verses.comment: This verse echoes Genesis, showing humanity's stewardship of creation. Wisdom here is personified, a theme that develops further in the New Testament.

verses.text: and to govern the world in holiness and righteousness, and to pass judgment with uprightness of heart;
verses.comment: Proper governance is rooted in divine wisdom, leading to holiness and justice—anticipating Christ's perfect kingship.

verses.text: give me Wisdom, who stands by your throne, and do not exclude me from the number of your children.
verses.comment: Wisdom is depicted as a person at God's side, linking to the Logos (Word) concept in early Christian thought and the person of Christ.

verses.text: For I am your servant and the son of your maidservant, a man who is weak and short-lived, with little understanding of judgment and laws.
verses.comment: The humility of the speaker acknowledges human frailty and dependence on divine guidance, a theme fulfilled in Christ’s submission.

verses.text: For if anyone among men be perfect, yet lacking the Wisdom that comes from you, he shall be regarded as nothing.
verses.comment: Perfect human wisdom is insufficient without God’s wisdom, alluding to the folly of Greek wisdom without Christ.

verses.text: You have chosen me to be king over your people and judge of your sons and daughters,
verses.comment: Solomon is the speaker, echoing his prayer for wisdom to rule, which foreshadows the wisdom Christ embodies as King.

verses.text: and have commanded me to build a temple on your holy mountain and an altar in the city of your dwelling—a copy of the holy tent you had prepared from the beginning.
verses.comment: The earthly temple is patterned after a heavenly reality, which the New Testament reveals is fulfilled in Christ (Heb. 8:5).

verses.text: With you is Wisdom, who knows your works and was present when you made the world; she understands what is pleasing in your eyes and what is right according to your commandments.
verses.comment: Divine Wisdom's personhood and preexistence foreshadow New Testament teachings about Christ as the Wisdom and Word of God.

verses.text: Send her out from the holy heavens, and from the throne of your glory, that she may labor with me and teach me what you are pleased with.
verses.comment: The request for wisdom links to the sending of the Holy Spirit as Teacher in John 14.

verses.text: For she knows and understands all things, and she will guide me wisely in my actions and guard me with her glory.
verses.comment: Divine Wisdom gives not only insight but direction and protection, paralleling the guidance of God’s Spirit in the believer’s life.

verses.text: Then my works will be acceptable, and I will judge your people justly, and be worthy of my father’s throne.
verses.comment: Human works gain acceptance through divine wisdom—anticipating the need for God’s grace and guidance to act justly.

verses.text: For what man can know the counsel of God? Or who can understand what the Lord wills?
verses.comment: God’s thoughts are beyond full human understanding, a theme Paul repeats in Romans.

verses.text: For the plans of mortals are uncertain, and our reasonings are unstable;
verses.comment: Points to human limitation and the necessity of relying on God’s wisdom rather than merely human intellect.

verses.text: for a perishable body burdens the soul, and this earthly tent weighs down the searching mind.
verses.comment: Reflects human weakness and mortality. The language of the 'tent' is echoed in the New Testament teaching about the resurrection body.

verses.text: We struggle to know what is on earth, and to understand what is at hand is labor; but who has traced out what is in the heavens?
verses.comment: This verse shows the limits of human perception, highlighting the value of divine revelation.

verses.text: And who could have learned your counsel, unless you had given Wisdom and sent your holy spirit from on high?
verses.comment: Divine wisdom and the giving of the Holy Spirit are necessary for understanding, a concept developed fully in the New Testament (Acts 2).

verses.text: Thus the paths of those on earth are set right, and people are taught what pleases you. By Wisdom they are saved.
verses.comment: Salvation and true knowledge come through divine Wisdom, who is ultimately revealed in Christ (1 Cor. 1:24). There is a strong tradition of interpreting Wisdom as both the personification of God’s power and a type of the Incarnate Word.
